Award.AwardTitle: NSF/CBMS Regional Conference in the Mathematical Sciences - "Solitons in Two-Dimensional Water Waves and Applications to Tsunami"
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support an NSF/CMBS regional conference to be held at University of Texas - Pan American in the summer of 2013 on solitons in two-dimensional water waves and applications to tsunamis. The principal speaker will be Professor Yuji Kodama from Ohio State University. The lectures will cover such areas as Grassmannians, two-dimensional soliton solutions and stability, and the Mach reflection problem. In addition to the 10 main lectures by Dr. Kodama, lectures will be presented by other experts in the field.

Hallmarks of the NSF/CBMS regional conference series are focus on a single important and timely area of research by a leading practitioner, a published monograph for a wider audience, and continued effect and local stimulation through regional recruitment emphasis. This conference will also entail a lecture aimed at the public on Japan's tsunamis. This award will support approximately 30 participants in the conference, many at early stages of their careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Professor Yuji Kodama, Ohio State University, delivered ten lectures on solitons in two-dimensional water waves and applications to tsunami. The objective of the lectures is to give a self-contained and comprehensive exposition on the new developments in the subjects of solitons in two-dimensional water waves and applications to tsunamis. The conference brought together a diverse group of researchers and students who are interested in nonlinear waves, water waves, solitons, integrable systems and tsunamis. We aimed to support the attendance of 30 researchers and students. The goals of this conference are: (1) to deliver the lecture series on mathematical models of two-dimensional water waves and applications of the models to tsunamis. These are new developments in the analysis of water waves, an area that has been extremely active in the last decade. (2) to bring together leading researchers, junior researchers and students who are interested in water waves, integrable systems, tsunamis and other related fields in mathematics/applied mathematics to share ideas and methods, (3) provide an opportunity for junior researchers and students from various fields to interact with more experienced researchers, and (4) to advance the research programs of these fields and applications to tsunamis, particularly through the inclusion of junior researchers and minority students.

The topics of the conference is of great scientific interest after Japan’s tsunami in March 11, 2011. The study of solitons in two-dimensional water waves has seen an explosive expansion of research results in the past few years. The mathematical theory of solitons in two-dimensional water waves has been recently developed by Prof. Yuji Kodama and his collaborators. The conference speakers reported the latest theoretical and experimental results in solitons in two-dimensional water waves and tsunamis. The conference represented an opportunity to provide a significant advancement to these areas through the interaction of a diverse body of researchers and students. The conference stimulated interest in research, teaching and learning of undergraduate/graduate students and faculty of mathematics, science and engineering at The University of Texas - Pan American and other local institutions located in South Texas. The impact was further broaden through the inclusion of women and minorities in the group of supported researchers brought to this conference. The University of Texas - Pan American is a minority serving institution and numerous students from our school attended this conference. The public lecture on tsunami was organized during the conference, and two experts on tsunami delivered lectures about tsunami. This event attracted many people in the community. The impact of the activity included:

•  The conference provided 10 lectures by Prof. Yuji Kodama and 9 tutorial lectures by experts. Lecture notes with homework problems were provided during the conference.

•  Participation of women (7), minorities (8), students (23), a postdoc. The total number of participants is 53.

•  The conference provided an opportunity for a broad interaction between mathematicians and scientists working in nonlinear waves and tsunamis to work together.

•  A poster session for students and young researchers to present their work in a relaxed atmosphere.

•  A short communication session for students to present their work.

•  Public lecture on tsunami attracted many people in the Rio Grande Valley (more than 120 people). This lecture was also streamed live on internet.
